metadata.subject: Time for a 'Belt and Sea Lane' for Latin America; Xi's philosophy for engaging with the world embodied in initiative; Establishing green routes for growth

organizations: U.S. House Committee on Oversight and Accountability
International Coalition for Green Development on the Belt and Road

relationships.description: China is the main purchaser of South American commodities and an important lender and investor
President Xi Jinping is hosting the Belt and Road Forum and his philosophy guides the initiative
Signed an agreement to promote sustainable development of the Belt and Road

analysis.purpose: To analyze geopolitical and economic opportunities for China in Latin America following Trump's election and promote the Belt and Road Initiative expansion
analysis.significance: Strategic analysis of shifting global power dynamics and China's opportunity to expand influence in Latin America

notable_quotes: South America swayed from the 'lost half decade' of 1998-2003, to the 'golden decade' of 2004-14, and this change happened mainly because of China.
The dividing line became clear: in Latin America, south of the Panama Canal the economic driver is China, north of the Panama Canal it still is the US.
This is the right time to show that while some want to build walls to divide and separate, China wants to build a bridge across the Pacific to integrate and link Asia and Latin America.

blackmail_indicators.description: No indicators of blackmail or coercion found in this analytical news article

illegal_activity.description: Document is a news article analysis published in China Daily discussing geopolitical and economic strategies, not involving first-hand illegal activity

details: Article published in China Daily featuring analysis by former Bolivian president and other experts

public_knowledge.context: Analysis of China's Belt and Road Initiative and its potential expansion to Latin America, published in official media outlet

analysis.summary: This China Daily article analyzes opportunities for China to expand its Belt and Road Initiative to Latin America following geopolitical shifts including Trump's election and the end of populism in South America, featuring perspectives from former Bolivian President Jorge-Tuto Quiroga, commentator Robert Lawrence Kuhn, and UN Environment head Erik Solheim on sustainable development aspects.
